result.title: Objective
result.description: Removal of barriers that have persistently hindered the widespread development an application of EE bricks and EE buildings in rural China

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Annual Reduction in CO2 emissions from rural brick production and from the C&R buildings in rural areas by end-of-project (EOP), ton/yea

actual.comment: 47157: Based on M&E experts reports on all demonstration EE brick manufacturing plants and 3 demonstration EE building projects. Further energy savings and CO2 reduction data are expected from the replication EE brick manufacturing plants and EE rural building projects (both demonstration and replication) from the M&E reports that will be available by the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Cumulative CO2 emission reduction in rural brick production and from the C&R buildings in rural areas by EOP, ton

actual.comment:
215,763
Based on M&E experts reports on all demonstration EE brick manufacturing plants and 3 demonstration EE building projects. Further energy savings and CO2 reduction data are expected from the replication EE brick manufacturing plants and EE rural building projects (both demonstration and replication) from the M&E reports that will be available by the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduction in total energy use in rural building sector and in rural brick making industry by EOP, tce;

actual.comment:
74,401
Based on the draft final report of demonstration EE brick M&E and investigation of completed demonstration EE building project in Xianyang. The final verified value is less than that reported in 2013 PIR due to the revision of EE brick M&E report.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: % improvement in energy efficiency in targeted rural buildings by EOP

actual.comment:
50%-56.2%
Based on the on-site measurement and verification reports on the completed demonstration EE building projects in Xianyang, Shan’xi Province; Jiling Province; and Xinjiang Autonomous Region.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: % improvement in energy efficiency in targeted rural brick makers by EO

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
% share of EE brick products in the targeted local rural building construction materials market
by EOP

actual.comment:
0.3-0.8
More precise analysis will be done and completed by the market evaluation experts by the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: % of rural buildings in the targeted local areas that are considered as EE buildings by EOP

actual.comment:
0.2-0.5
The survey questionnaire for collecting more complete and precise data had been sent by the PMO to LPMOs and projects sites in May 2015. The results of the survey and of the data analyses will be available later this year.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced knowledge and access to technical and market information, particularly among local governments, rural residents, and builders in rural areas, on EE bricks and buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: An operational EE Brick & EE Building information dissemination network by Year 3

target.comment: Operational starting year 3

actual.comment:
3
One more than that reported in 2014 PIR. This is a more comprehensive project info website, and will be in full operation later this year.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of multi-media product packages developed and disseminated per year starting Year 3

actual.comment:
6
One more than that reported in 2014 PIR. This is an educational film on EE buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of completed promotion and advocacy program by EOP

actual.comment:
9
3 more than that reported in 2014 PIR. These are on the EE building materials and EE building public promotion initiated jointly by PMO with local governments in Sichuan and Zhejiang Provinces, and the project best practices knowledge sharing workshop sponsored by the PMO in April 2015 in Chengdu, Sichuan Province. Representative and journalists from Chinese Farmer’s Daily, China National Radio, and Chinese agriculture and local newspapers were in attendance and reported about the workshop proceedings.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of people reached by project information dissemination network and public awareness campaign starting Year 1

target.comment: at least 1 million

actual.comment:
15 Million
PMO estimate based on circulations (readerships) of leading mass media organizations such as the Chinese Farmers’ Daily, China National Radio, web sites of Chinese agricultural organizations and other Sichuan local newspapers news coverage for the April 2015 project activity.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Promulgation of, and compliance to, favorable policies that encourage manufacturing and utilization of EE bricks and the application of EE technologies and practices in the buildings sector in the countryâ€™s rural areas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of project policy proposals incorporated into the national EE building and rural development decision making processes by EOP

actual.comment:
5
One more than that in 2014 PIR. This is the newly issued value added tax waiver and reduction policy by MOF on new building materials production (including the EE bricks promoted by the project). The proposals made by the project subcontractors (financially supported by the project) facilitated the formulation of the policy and its issuance.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of standards and codes on rural EE buildings developed and approved by the local government authorities by EOP

target.comment: at least 1

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of local governments that have incorporated rural EE building application and EE brick production into their local development planning and action plan implementation by EOP

target.comment: at least 10

actual.comment:
7
The survey questionnaire for collecting more complete and precise data had been sent by the PMO to LPMOs and projects sites in May 2015. Further updates will be available later this year.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Finance Support & Accessibility Improvement

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of financial institutions involved in the project by EOP

target.comment: at least 40

actual.comment:
34
Preliminary PMO estimate based on discussions with the financial institutions involved in the EE brick making demonstrations and replications.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total amount of funds (RMB) leveraged by the project into the rural EE building construction and brick production by EOP

target.comment: at least 50 million

actual.comment:
2,012 million
Based on the investigation and survey made by the PMO on completed demonstration and replication projects.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Demonstration and Technology Support

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Total number of rural brick mills making EEbricks by EOP;

target.comment: at least 28

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total output of EE bricks (pieces) in the targeted rural areas by EOP

target.comment: at least 1.5 billion

actual.comment:
1041 million
Based on the PMO update report on completed EE brick making projects. Further updates will be conducted by M&E experts, and the results will be available later this year.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Total rural EE buildings constructed in targeted areas by EOP

target.comment: at least 1760

actual.comment:
7765
Based on the investigation and survey made by the PMO on completed demonstration and replication projects.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Project Objective: Significantly improved room air conditioner energy efficiency in China.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Average RAC energy efficiency gain by EOP, %

target.comment:
10
Based on annual reports submitted by RAC manufacturers to the AC Market Information System (AMIS).

actual.comment: This data was analyzed by AMIS, while AMIS submits its annual report by the end of each year. In this case, the latest EER/SEER is data in2013. The average constant frequency of RAC EE (EER) saw the rise of 18.9% compared to baseline; and the variable frequency RAC (SEER) is 31.0%.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Cumulative energy savings from the use of EE RACs by EOP, Mtce

actual.comment: This data was based on the annual report handled by manufactures, which submit by the end of each year. In this case, the latest energy saving from the use of EE RACs is 5312.49Mtce

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: AC Compressor Efficiency Upgrades

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Average AC compressor efficiency (COP) by EOP

actual.comment: As mentioned in Objective 1, the latest the average constant frequency of ACC COP is 3.07 and the variable frequency ACC COP is 3.59 in 2013.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: EE ACC market share by EOP, %

actual.comment: The standard of EE ACC has not been released. According to AMIS Report, the market share of constant frequency ACC which COP higher than 3.2 is 24.1%, while the variable frequency ACC which COP higher than 3.8 is 51.4%

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of interested ACC manufacturers that are planning to produce or already producing the new EE ACC models by EOP

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Percentage of ACC manufacturers submitting reports each year to AMIS starting Year 1, %

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Proportion of ACC manufacturers that made use of the product testing results in improving their EE ACC products by EOP, %

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: RAC Efficiency Upgrades

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Average RAC (EER) by EOP

actual.comment: As mentioned in Objective 1, the latest data of the average constant frequency RAC EER in 2013 is 3.33; and the variable frequency RAC SEER is 4.39

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: EE RAC market share by EOP, %

actual.comment: As mentioned in Objective 1, the latest data of the constant frequency EE RAC market share is 37.6%, and the variable frequency EE RAC is 43%

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of interested RAC manufacturers that are planning to produce or already producing the new EE RAC models by EOP

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: % of RAC manufacturers that indicated they can comply with the new set minimum EER standards

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Percentage of RAC manufacturers submitting reports each year to AMIS starting Year 1, %

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Proportion of RAC manufacturers that made use of the product testing results in improving their EE RAC products by EOP, %

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Energy Efficient RAC Promotion

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of EE RACs that were sold under the Retail Incentive Program by EOP

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of RAC manufacturers by EOP that find the RAC Retailer Program useful for promoting EE RACs, and committed to strategically employ it after PEERAC

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of RAC manufacturers that committed to develop and implement a rebate/recycling program by end Year 3

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of rebate/recycling program plans approved by the PEERAC PAC by end Year 4

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Total number of inefficient RACs retired, recycled, and replaced with new efficient ones through the approved rebate/recycling programs by end Year 5

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: % of RAC brands that qualify for the new EE RAC energy label by EOP, %

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: EE RAC market share by EOP, %

actual.comment: the constant frequency EE RAC market share is 37.6%, and the variable frequency EE RAC is 43%

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: US$ value of EE RAC project related advertising placed by manufacturers by end Year 5

target.comment: 7.5 million

actual.comment: About 19.73million USD (122.32million RMB @ RMB 6.201/USD)

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Share of RAC advertising by manufacturers for high efficiency products by EOP, %

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: % Increase in number of consumers that are either planning or are ready to purchase EE RAC by EOP

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: % of cumulative EE RAC sales that were directly influenced by the PR campaigns by EOP, %

indicator.description: Selected indicator species that are rare and threatened show stable or upward trends in numbers (including inter alia wild yak, wild ass, Tibetan antelope, snow leopard, Pallas' cat, musk deer, white-lipped deer, black-necked crane, etc.)

baseline.comment:
Baseline survey of selected indicator species at outset of project, in three target units of the SNNR (Suojia-Qumahe, Zhaling-Elinghu, Makahe) which were conducted in 2014. Population of wild animals of Suojia-Qumahe Block(It is the population of sampling survey):
- Tibetan Ass:272
- Tibetan gazelles: 150
- Tibetan Antelope: 115
Population of wild animals of Zhaling-Elinghhu Block: Sampled Tansect-1
- Tibetan Ass:103
- Tibetan gazelles: 37
- Upland buzzard: 5
- Bar-headed goose: 4
Sampled Tansect-2
- Tibetan Ass:2
- Tibetan gazelles: 6
- Upland buzzard: 9
- Bar-headed goose: 128
Population of wild animals of Makehe Block(It takes Yaba Valley as the sample): Greenish warbler: 1
- Marsh Tit: 55
- Falco peregrinus: 1
- Blue Eared Pheasant:8
- Himalayan Beautiful Rosefinch:70
- Macaque: 27

target.comment: Key wildlife populations maintained or increasing; appropriate population structure

actual.comment: Baseline was established and entered in this PIR. Annual monitoring will be carried out in July-August 2015

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Mainstreaming PA management into provincial development and sector planning process

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: PA system and its management mainstreamed within the provincial sectoral and development planning framework at the provincial level: indicated by clear inclusion of due consideration and concrete measures for biodiversity conservation and PA development, as well as ear marked budget in the sectoral development plans at provincial levels and in the (national) 13th 5-year plan.

baseline.comment:
No sectoral plans integrate PA objectives
Development plans include no vision and development plan for PAs and no link is made between the PAs and development, nor no concrete measure for biodiversity conservation

target.comment:
At least 3 sectoral plans integrate consideration of PAs and of biodiversity conservation measures
13th Five-Year Plan recognises clear linkage between PAs and provincial development, and includes PA- and biodiversity-related targets and budgets

actual.comment: "1+5" model was formed that stands for Provincial 13th Five-Year Plan ("1"), Provincial Development and Reform Commission, 13th Five-Year Plan of Land Resources, 13th Five-Year Plan of Agro-husbandry Department, 13th Five-Year Plan of Water Conservancy Department,13th Five-Year Plan of Environmental Protection Department ("5"). 13th Five-Year Plans were integrated with BSAP through inter-sectoral advisory group that was facilitated by GEF project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Threats to PAs from infrastructure placement (roads, dams) and other adverse forms of land use avoided, mitigated or offset, leading to more effective conservation in Qinghai's PA system covering 251,665km2.

baseline.comment: No procedure in place to deal with incompatible developments

target.comment: Official standards for infrastructure development and operation within the PAs are developed and operationalised, with clear rehabilitation/offset mechanism.

actual.comment: 'Transportation and Traffic Infra-construction Environmental Protection Regulation and Technical Guidelines' and 'Infra-construction Environmental Protection Regulation of State Grid Qinghai Company and Technical Guidelines' was reviewed and will be enacted in 2015.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Increasing PA management effectiveness through strengthened institutional and staff capacities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Capacity development scorecard (%) for the protected area system.

actual.comment: PMO and Wildlife and Nature Reserve Management Bureau conducted the mid-term capacity Development Scorecard assessment. The Score is 63.6% in May 2015. To date, 17 batches of training courses with covering 11 topics were delivered to 440 trainees including 127 women(28.8%) who are from PA managers and technical staff as well as community wardens.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Strategic plans prepared for PA institutions and procedures and investment, and PA staff numbers dramatically increased
- Permanent staff
- Temporary staff

baseline.comment:
No strategic plans
160
5

target.comment:
Strategic Plan developed and adopted
360
150

actual.comment:
Permanent Staff: 231
Temporary staff(Contracted):273
According to the official document provided by Personnel Division of QFD, there is an increase of 118 staff in PA staff who are mainly forestry policemen of SNNR and QFD as well as staff of Qilian Mountain NR and an increase of 273 in contracted staff (Ecological public service positions) during the year of 2013-2014. Major reason is based on nature reserve institutional strengthening strategy plan of Province in order to enhance enforcement of PA management and forestry management. GEF promoted the process of the strengthening plan through nature reserve management plan development and offered advice on nature reserve institutional strengthening.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Province’s system level PA financing increased to close the existing annual financing gap of US$ 4.6 million for basic expenditure scenario (tracked with PA financial sustainability scorecard)

baseline.comment: US$ 2 million / year

target.comment: US$ 6.6 million per year

actual.comment:
US$19.3 million per year
According to financial scorecard in 2014. The total revenue of PA system was respectively US$2.83million, US$19.3 million in 2011 and in 2014. Of which, 7.21 million is field operational fee and 10.54 million is an investment for infrastructure construction. The financial data of 7 nature reserves is only available since the other nature reserves don't have discretionary authority, independent financial accounts. The reason for financial increase are investment from the central government includes infrastructure, capacity building, conservation, Research and publicity and education and other investment from external cooperative research and ecotourism.
GEF levers co-finance from the government together to made its contribution of $2.37million to PAs.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Ratio of total PA budget spent on field operations raised to narrow spending gap

baseline.comment:
10% of PA revenue
spent on field operations

target.comment:
30% of PA revenue
spent on field operations

actual.comment:
19.2% in 2014.
According to the financial scorecards, the total revenue is US$13,054,000,of which spending on operations and infrastructures are respectively US$2,514,000 and US$10,540,000. The field operational cost of PAs accounts for 19.2% of the total expenditure in 2014. This ratio would be fluctuant in terms of the amount of infrastructure investment of PAs sponsored by the central government.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Reduction in illegal incident cases within the NRs eg.poaching, illegal harvesting, illegal-grazing, etc.

baseline.comment:
Currently no monitoring system in place.
Baseline for the number of illegal incidents will be estimated at onset of the project.

target.comment:
Functioning policing records system with links to police/ court cases and an enhanced policing mandate of NR staff.
Routine report forms designed for numerical analysis.
Incidents reduced to 50% of the baseline level.

actual.comment:
According to the annual report of Forestry Police Bureau of QFD, illegal incidents were respectively as follow:
2011: 1942 cases in total consisted of 34 criminal cases and 1908 administrative cases.
2012: 1968 cases in total consisted of 22 criminal cases and 1946 administrative cases.
2013: 1872 cases in total consisted of 24 criminal cases and 1848 administrative cases.
2014: 1199 cases in total consisted of 56 criminal cases and 1143 administrative cases.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Annual income diverted to PA management from eco-compensation agreements (excluding funds arising from the Sanjiangyuan Ecological Construction Plan)

target.comment: US$1.0m

actual.comment:
$1.589 million per year.
The financial resources are from the central government excluding the Sanjiangyuan Ecological Construction Plan that is eco-compensation arrangement from the central government.
According to the financial scorecard assessment, the total investment to PAs was $13 million in 2014. Among which, operational cost is $2.514 million and infrastructure investment is $10.54million which includes infrastructure, conservation, capacity building, Research and publicity and education. However, rarely in road and visitor center construction. If excluding the investment to SNNR, the investment to other PAs is about $1.589 million.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: More representative PA system approved with most of ‘major vegetation types’ represented (5% coverage) in the NNR's

baseline.comment: 13 of 30 habitats

target.comment:
22 of 30 habitats
(addition of desert and Qilian montane habitats, with an overall increase of 18,000,000 ha in the provincial PA system)

actual.comment: Wildlife and Nature Reserve Management Bureau of Qinghai Forestry Department thought that the provincial PAs Development Plan (2011-2020) has covered with more representatives of eco-region and vegetation types, in which, some targets have been achieved. Instead, they prefer to develop Qinghai PA monitoring plan, which is consistence with State Forestry Administration's funding strategy and the strengthening of PAs management effectiveness is one of GEF project's priorities. In terms of this consideration, GEF sponsored the development of Qinghai PA monitoring plan and PMO asked a specialist to conduct a mapping analysis between vegetations and existing PAs in 2015, which indicates the representatives of vegetations and eco-regions in Qinghai and gaps of PAs coverage and also includes the recommendations to future PA system planning.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Demonstration of Effective PA management through community involvement in the Sanjiangyuan National Nature Reserve (SNNR)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Extent of area (ha) closed from domestic grazing
Area of open corridors
Area within the PA under community co-management

baseline.comment: 1,000 km ², 0 km ², 2,440 km ²

target.comment:
4,000 km ²
500 km ²
8,886 km ² (or more)

actual.comment: Community-oriented zoning was introduced in November, 2013 and practiced in Qumahe in 2014. PMO plans to apply the methodology in 12 pilot villages in 2015. Then, the zoning results will be mapped.

indicator.description: Increase in the key species number and distributions in target co-management community sites (up to 12 community field sites)

baseline.comment:
Baseline survey of selected indicator species at outset of project, in three target units of the SNNR (Suojia-Qumahe, Zhaling-Elinghu, Makahe) that were conducted in 2014. Population of wild animals of Suojia-Qumahe Block(It is the population of sampling survey):

Population of wild animals of Zhaling-Elinghhu Block: Sampled Tansect-1
- Tibetan Ass:103
- Tibetan gazelles: 37

Sampled Tansect-2
- Tibetan Ass:2
- Tibetan gazelles: 6
- Upland buzzard: 9
- Bar-headed goose: 128
Population of wild animals of Makehe Block(It takes Yaba Valley as the sample): Greenish warbler: 1
- Marsh Tit: 55
- Falco peregrinus: 1
- Blue Eared Pheasant:8
- Himalayan Beautiful Rosefinch:70
- Macaque: 27

target.comment:
Key wildlife populations maintained or increasing
in co-management areas

actual.comment: Baseline survey was conducted and results are entered in the PIR. Annual monitoring is planned to carry out in July-August 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Management effectiveness increased in SNNR due to co-management arrangements using the METT tracking tool

baseline.comment:
32%
Management unit baselines TBD at
onset of project

actual.comment: 59% in 2014 This score was assessed by PA staff under Prof. Li Diqiang's guidance during the METT workshop in March, 2015. The reasons of the improvement are that SNNR has been improving its management procedure, staff capacity, resource inventory and research, monitoring, finance, co-management etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Number of private-NR or of community co-management agreements:
- Private enterprise management agreements
- Informal, non-binding, agreements
- Formal, legally binding, agreements

target.comment: At least 1 , 10 agreements, 2 agreements

actual.comment: 12 village administrations signed respectively tripartite co-management agreements among villages administration, SNNR and PMO in 2014.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Awareness surveys among communities show increased positive attitude towards PA conservation

baseline.comment:
Baseline awareness TBD by Knowledge Attitudes & Practice (KAP) survey at onset of project according to Participatory Rural Assessment in Qumahe Township in 2013
- Angla Village: 76% of interviewees were concerned for wildlife, 76% of interviewees can identify at least 2 endangered species.
- Duoxiu Village: 86% of interviewees were concerned for wildlife, 80% of interviewees can identify at least 2 endangered species.
- Cuochi Village:95% of interviewees were concerned for wildlife.

target.comment: Baseline + 50% positive attitude

actual.comment: The project conducted baseline awareness assessment(KAP) in 4 pilot villages of Qumahe Township in 2013 though it was not so comprehensive. Environmental awareness was presented very high among the 4 pilot villages as there have been community development support extended there for several years The GEF project has also made contributions to raising awareness among local communities residing within or near PA’s. According to the results of MTR questionnaire interview in Duoxiu and Cuochi Villages, awareness among target communities has been enhanced that about 95% of interviewees are satisfied with the GEF project, knowing the co-management agreement and benefiting to herders respectively.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the sub-system of wetland protected areas to respond to existing and emerging threats to their globally significant biodiversity.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: GEF Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) scores of the six Provincial Projects of the MSL Program

baseline.comment: Average score of the 41 protected areas in the six provincial projects of the MSL Program is 47 (Annex 7)

target.comment: Average of the 41 protected areas in the six project provinces METT increasing to a score of 64

actual.comment: Average score of the 41 protected areas in the six provincial projects of the MSL Program is 47, new score need to be updated at MTR, The number of PAs of Anhui project increased from 6 to 7, so the baseline, target of METT was adjusted accordingly, the total number of PAs in the six project provinces increased from 41 to 42, the rest of provincial projects still keep the baseline and all the six provincial project have been listed the METT training as one of their project activities before MTR-to be followed up by SUN

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Level of adoption of the GEF Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) at the wetland PA sub-system level

baseline.comment: Currently no systematic use of the METT

target.comment: At the end of the project, 20% of the country's wetland PAs will have adopted the use of the METT as a regular monitoring tool.

actual.comment: To be updated at MTR, the project will facilitate OWCM/SFA adopt the use of METT as a regular monitoring tool

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: UNDP Capacity Assessment Scorecard for selected agencies involved or impacting upon wetland management (annex 6)

baseline.comment:
SFA (50%)
MEP (55%)
SOA (54%)
Additional agencies to be added at Project Inception
(Annex 6)

target.comment:
An Increase of 25 percentage point for each Agency, i.e.,
SFA to 75%,
MEP to 80%,
SOA to 79%, others TBD

actual.comment: To be updated at MTR and TE respectively.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Wetland PA Sub-System Strengthened through Better Ecological Representation and Enhanced Management Capacity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1.1. Coverage of natural wetlands in the national PA network increased from the baseline of 50.3% to 52% by adding an extra 615,400 hectares under protection contributing towards the collective programmatic expansion target of 55%.

baseline.comment:
Natural Lakes (53%)
Coastal Wetlands (61%)
Riverine Wetlands (32%)
Marshes (55%)
TOTAL (50.3%)

target.comment:
Natural Lakes (58%)
Coastal Wetlands (67%)
Riverine Wetlands (35%)
Marshes (61%)
TOTAL (55%)

actual.comment: Indicator values remain unchanged as the baseline, i.e. Natural Lakes (53%); Coastal Wetlands (61%); Riverine Wetlands (32%); Marshes (55%). TOTAL (50.3%), and will be updated by the MTR. 1. A service contract has been awarded and in process well to contribute in this aspect. 2. 140 national parks (trial) have been newly established in 2014, and 9 more than the statistic figures of 2013. 343,700 hectares natural wetlands increased as newly adding protected area in 2014. The protection rate of natural wetlands was 45.33% in 2013, and increased to 46.06% in 2014.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 1.2. Ecosystem Health Index (EHI) monitoring systems for monitoring wetland health fine-tuned and in place for the entire sub-system, with a focus to reduce threats.

baseline.comment: Currently no use. The EHI has been developed during the PPG stage but will be fine-tuned based on implementation experience emerging from the provincial projects and other existing indexes (e.g., the WEEIS) (Annex 1).

target.comment: Fine-tuning and wide adoption of EHI at the sub-system wetland PA level.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: External threats to Wetland PAs reduced through mainstreaming wetland PA considerations in sector planning

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1.a. Safeguards from sector practices for MOA, MOWR, MLWR, and MEP in place and in use.

baseline.comment: No safeguards for wetland PAs.

target.comment: Safeguards in the form of standards and procedures in place for each sector, and used centrally by SFA to avoid threats from external sectors.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.2. Increased national financing for wetland PA management (funds and number of mechanisms) as recorded in the financial sustainability scorecard

baseline.comment:
Baseline amount is the national budget allocation of US$87.95 Million per year for operation (US$ 35,170,000) and infrastructure (US$ 52,780,000).
Financing mechanisms are mainly budget allocations. There is an eco-compensation program, however the funding provincial governments receive is not linked to PA management.

target.comment: Budget allocations for PA management operation increased by 50% over the baseline from national level sources (any sources, to be developed during implementation); and new sustainable financing mechanisms for PAs established and operational including earmarking of eco-compensation program funding for wetland PA management.

actual.comment:
The project helps SFA in allocation of funding for wetland programme nationally. The national budget allocation rises fast and now at US$300 Million in 2014 (263.01million for operations; 36.99 million for infrastructure covering. 63 projects with about 500,000 hectares wetlands added as beneficiary. The policy of central government subsidies to wetlands have been implemented very well in 2014, the central government allocated special funds to start pilot programme of farmland to wetlands, pilot programme of wetland ecological compensation , pilot wetland conservation incentives, and the continued implementation of wetland conservation and restoration programmes, 268 projects were arranged, the total amount subsidies of 2014 was about USD263.01million, , increased 1.2 and 5.4 times respectively than 2013. The specified funding allocation of 2014 is as following: USD82.84 million for wetlands conservation and restoration; USD24.67 million for pilot programme of returning farmland to wetlands; USD 105.2million for wetland ecological compensation programme; about USD49.31 million for pilot wetland conservation incentives.
These figure already exceed targets for funding set forth in PD.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Increased knowledge management, lessons sharing, and awareness for wetland PAs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 3.1. Improved data sharing platform regularly updated, as indicated by use levels of data providers and data users including their usefulness.

baseline.comment: No use. Currently, the SFA lacks a comprehensive system to manage wetland data at the sub-system level.

target.comment: Data sharing platform in use in the form of a virtual database, containing basic wetland PA data from all the PA agencies providing necessary information for wetland PA managers for their management decision making

actual.comment: Data base development has been designed as a very important part under outcome 3, during the period of project implementation, OWCM/SFA has taken the lead and organized a group of experts to establish the virtual database by Chinese partner supporting funding based on the demands and needs of wetland development in China. And the project funds planned for this purpose has been decided to shift for other policies research through the discussion with OWCM/SFA and UNDP China.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 3.2. Public and government have better understanding and better access to information about wetland issues, indicated by results of the KAP surveys (Annex 4)

baseline.comment: KAP survey has been commissioned through the PPG and a baseline has been measured for the national level project in Beijing and for some of the provincial projects. The baseline is a score of 111.5 of 216 in Beijing (52%).

target.comment: 30% improvement in KAP survey results (i.e., a score of 173 or 82%).

actual.comment: indicator scores remain unchanged as the baseline, i.e. 111.5 of 216 in Beijing (52%), and will be updated by the MTR.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3.3. Magnitude and coverage of lessons disseminated.

baseline.comment: No program level system to track or disseminate lessons.

target.comment: Programmatic monitoring system in place as per the Program Framework and program level reporting is in place. Lessons documented and shared widely. Wetland PA Program Steering and Coordination Forum established

actual.comment:
PSC meeting (2015) has been conducted successfully on Apr.22-23,2015 in Honghu county, Heibei Province;
Project website( www.gefwetland.com) has been established and operated, information, experiences and lessons sharing are more widely and efficient; Wechat group has been established and use for daily communication among all projects stakeholders

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the management effectiveness of the wetland protected area system in Hainan in response to existing and emerging threats to the globally significant biodiversity and essential ecosystem services

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The area of ecosystems covered by Hainan’s terrestrial PA system increases by at least 40,000 ha with improved coverage of under-represented types by 2018 in line with the draft PA System Master Plan, project strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem and climate change resilience strategy.

baseline.comment:
Hainan’s terrestrial PA system covers 285,600 ha
Vegetation Type | Current (Km2)
32a | 7.6
33a | 9.6
41a | 8.5
43c | 0
44 | 36.5
80b | 1.5

target.comment:
Hainan’s terrestrial PA system covers at least 325,600 ha by 2018
Vegetation Type | Target (Km2)
32a | 15
33a | 15
41a | 15
43c | 15
44 | 40
80b | 5

actual.comment:
In 2013, Hainan Forestry Department promoted the establishment of 1 national forest park and approved the establishment of 12 provincial forest parks. The coverage of Hainan terrestrial PAs has been increased by 29,516 ha.
From 2014 till now, 2 new provincial nature reserves are in the process of applying for approval, which are E'xianling NR (forest ecosystem) with an area of 4,490ha and Yanding NR (mangrove ecosystem) with an area of 160ha. A privately-owned wetland park, Baolinggang WP with an area of about 100ha, is now under design and planned to start construction by end of 2015. The wetland park is owned by a renowned real estate company, Luneng Group, and they are keen to follow the ecological concept in the wetland park construction with the support of the project. A memorandum of understanding is drafted by the Project to include the wetland park as one demonstration site of Hainan GEF project. However, the area of vegetation type is not yet updated, because the Hainan PA Master Plan is not yet approved and this category was not applied during the 2nd National Wetland Inventory Assessment. This issue will be put forward during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Strengthened management effectiveness of 7 PAs in the Hainan Mangrove PA Network indicated by METT scores:
Dongzhaigang NNR
Xinying Mangrove NWP
Qinglangang PNR
Dongfang PNR
Sanya City NR
Xinying Bay City NR
Huachang Bay County NR

baseline.comment:
METT Baseline scores:
43
26
39
45
30
15
27

target.comment:
METT target scores:
70
50
60
65
50
50
50

actual.comment: To better improve the capacity of PA management, a professional competency standard for Hainan NRs' staff was drafted with reference to the "Competence Standards for Protected Area Jobs in South East Asia" developed by ASEAN Regional Center for Biodiversity Conservation(ARCBC), and on the basis of field assessment in 17 representative NRs, which are under respective supervision by Hainan Forestry Department, Hainan Land, Environment and Resources Department and Hainan Marine and Fisheries Department. The draft has been revised according to the advice of a panel of experts, officials and NR representatives, and will be finalized by Aug. 2015. Furthermore, a training needs’ assessment was conducted in Oct. 2014 among all project related PAs, topics for future training were identified for PAs' staff at different level. By end of 2015, the METT evaluation will be conducted during the MTR.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Planned improvement in the financial sustainability of the provincial PA system at site and system level indicated by Part II of the GEF financial sustainability scorecard:
- Component 1 – Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks
- Component 2 – Business planning and tools for cost- effective management
- Component 3 – Tools for revenue generation

baseline.comment:
Financial scorecard baselines:
31%
31%
11%

target.comment:
Financial scorecard targets:
60%
56%
30%

actual.comment: In Sep. 2014, the revised "Hainan Provincial Regulation of Nature Reserve Management" was adopted by the Hainan Provincial People's Congress. According to the new regulation, the cost for provincial NR shall be included into the provincial budget plan, which can help to reduce the financing gap. By end of 2015, the financial sustainability evaluation will be conducted during the MTR.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Improved protection and management of Hainan’s ecosystems through expansion, consolidation and sustainable financing of the provincial PA system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Financing Plan for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem

baseline.comment: Master Plan for Hainan PA System awaiting approval, no financing plan

target.comment: Financing Plan approved for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem

actual.comment: The Master Plan for Hainan Nature Reserves Development is still under elaboration, which is led by the Hainan Environment Protection Department (formerly the Hainan Land Environment and Resources Department). Besides, based on the result of 2nd national wetland inventory, the master plan for Hainan wetland conservation is now under elaboration. The financial plan for the wetland PA sub-system will be developed afterwards.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: National and provincial financing for PA system through HFD increased to close the existing annual financing gap of US$6.69 million for basic expenditure scenario

baseline.comment:
Annual financing available for PA System:
US$ 8.06 million / year

target.comment:
Annual financing available for PA System + Projected annual financing gap for basic expenditure scenario in year 2012+5:
US$19.92 million per year

actual.comment: According to the statistic from the HFD, in 2014 the yearly overall financing for PA system is US$12.478 million from both national and provincial government. 4 project sites received in total about US$ 2.97million (CNY18.4 million) from the provincial government for wetland restoration by the end of 2014. The fund is mainly used in mangrove afforestation, converting ponds back to mangroves and infrastructure construction, such as boundary markers, watch towers, bird watching hides, entrance gates etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improved PA system management capacity of Hainan Forestry Department, Land Environment & Resources Department, and Marine and Fisheries Department as shown by the UNDP Capacity Scorecard

baseline.comment:
Capacity Scorecard baselines :
HFD: 50%
HLERD: 56%
HMFD: 74%

target.comment:
Capacity Scorecard targets:
HFD: 65%
HLERD: 65%
HMFD: 80%

actual.comment: To enhance the capacity in mangrove wetland restoration and management, the project organized 4 trainings for officials from local bureaus of forestry, land environment & resources, marine and fisheries, finance and tourism. Among the total participants of 141, 60 are government officials including 12 female. The capacity assessment will be carried out again during the MTR.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Strengthened protection, participatory management and restoration of mangrove forests through the development of a Mangrove PA Network (MPAN)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Operational MPAN is evident through:
i) Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans.
ii) Network coordination centre and training base established at Dongzhaigang NNR
iii) All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols

baseline.comment: Mangrove PAs are not networked, lack of common management methods and standards, limited information exchange

target.comment:
Operational MPAN evident through:
i) Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans.
ii) Network coordination centre and training base established at Dongzhaigang NNR
iii) All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols

actual.comment:
In Dec. 26, 2014, the establishment meeting of the MWPAN was held in Haikou. Directors from 10 project sites and the deputy director from Hainan Wild Animal and Plant Conservation Bureau, which is responsible for Hainan PAs management, attended the meeting. The Declaration of the Network was discussed, approved and signed by all member PAs on the meeting. The declaration states that the Network will organize at least one meeting per year, and a theme will be selected during the meeting, which is to be the key focus for all member PAs for the year. The theme for 2015 is biodiversity monitoring. A timetable for monthly monitoring was agreed upon by all members.
Necessary equipment including meeting room audio/visual equipment, professional cameras for bird photography and computers etc. were procured for the establishment of a training center in Dongzhaigang in the second half of 2014. After that, a training event was organized in Dongzhaigang on species identification and monitoring in Nov. 2014.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Improved ecosystem health status of the selected Hainan mangrove PA network sites, indicated by the improvement in the MSL’s Ecosystem Health Index (EHI)
*EHI baselines & targets to be established in Year 1 for other sites: Dongfang PNR, Sanya City NR, Xinying Bay City NR, Huachang Bay County NR

baseline.comment:
EHI baselines for selected sites*:
Dongzhaigang NNR:
0.468
Qinglangang PNR:
0.444
Xinying mangrove NWP:
0.441

target.comment:
EHI targets for selected sites*:
Dongzhaigang NNR:
0.600
Qinglangang PNR:
0.600
Xinying mangrove NWP:
0.600

actual.comment:
Dr. John MacKinnon was contracted as the international EHI specialists to facilitate the EHI baseline survey. After a training in March 2014, the survey was carried out in all project sites in April with the support of Dr. MacKinnon. In June, the EHI report and the baseline score was finalized and distributed to all sites. In addition, based on the survey, a monitoring protocol for each site was also developed by the specialist.
In order to have the baseline on the same timing for all selected sites, the project updated the baseline and target of EHI for all sites as following:
Dongzhaigang NNR 0.43/0.66
Qinglangang PNR 0.46/0.55
Xinying mangrove NWP 0.52/0.70
Dongfang NR 0.52/0.70
Sanya City NR, inclusive of 3 sites:
Sanya He NR 0.54/0.62
Qingmeigang NR 0.49/0.75
Tielugang NR 0.32/0.54
Xinying Bay City NR 0.40/0.69
Huachang Bay County NR (Hongshuwan WP) 0.43/0.75

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Increased protection status of selected wetland related reserves, taking full account of access and benefit sharing rights of indigenous / minority ethnic group stakeholders.
**Yinggeling is a forested catchment area for Haikou area

actual.comment:
During the inception workshop, the baseline and target of this indicator was discussed and proposed to be changed. The proposed change were as below:
1) change the listed Haiwei WP(not yet a Provincial WP) to Dongfang PNR, and its baseline level is PNR and the target is NNR.
2) change the target for Fanjia PNR to the demonstration PNR of wetland type.
3) change the target for Sanya CNR to demonstration CNR.
For the baseline, the Haiwei Wetland Park is not yet a provincial park. During the inception workshop, this problem was discussed and proposed to change to Dongfang PNR, of which the baseline level is PNR and the target is NNR. However, the approval procedure of this revision is not completed. So this issue will be re-discussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office .
Through about a year of preparation, application and assessment, by end of Dec. 2014, the state council announced that the Yinggeling NR was upgraded to national level Nature Reserve.
The project is now looking into the possibility to support the Dongfang PNR to get international designation, which is to be listed as an international site under the East Asian Australasian Flyway Programme, as the first step to apply for NNR.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increase in the number of wintering Black-faced Spoonbills Platalea minor in Hainan

baseline.comment: Wintering population of 76 BF Spoonbills

target.comment: Wintering population of 100 BF Spoonbills with a stable or increasing trend

actual.comment:
According to the result of the International Black-faced Spoonbill Census in every January, the number in Hainan slightly increased from 44 in 2012 to 56 in 2015.
In Aug. 2014, the local government planted about 57.3ha of mangrove seedling on the mudflat and beach inside the NR for the purpose of restoring mangrove forest and attracting more BF spoonbill. However, according to bird specialists, the planting efforts may have a negative impact. So based on the specialists' advice and previous studies on BF spoonbill, the project wrote an advice letter to the local government. In addition, during CTA's visits to Dongfang, this issue was openly discussed among the government officials. Now the government was highly aware of the problem and willing to take measures to make change.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Viable alternative options are demonstrated for target communities impacting mangrove resources at Dongzhaigang and Qinglangang that result in more sustainable resource use and include the equitable representation and involvement of women.

baseline.comment: No assistance available from PA system to help local communities with economic opportunities

target.comment: New co-management structures are established that support and strengthen alternative livelihood options for target communities, including equitable representation and involvement of women.

actual.comment: The project made efforts to explore feasible alternative livelihood for local residents around NRs, such as bee-raising, crab-raising etc. In Dongzhaigang, 4 households were selected and trained to demonstrate bee-raising.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Increased area of mangrove cover within and adjacent to project demonstration reserves through replanting activities in unproductive aquaculture ponds and other suitable areas

baseline.comment:
See table inset below for baseline area of mangrove cover and area of existing replanting efforts at selected sites
Site Mangrove Area Existing Replanted Area
Dongzhaigang NNR | 1578 ha | 60 ha
Qinglangang PNR | 1233 ha | 0 ha
Xinying NWP | 150 ha | <10 ha
<!--10-->
Dongfang PNR | 250 ha | <15 ha
<!--15-->
Sanya CNR | 60 ha | 10 ha
Total | 3271 ha | <95 ha

target.comment:
1,000 ha of mangrove forest replanted with native species at selected sites
Site Project Target Area (Additional Replanting)
Dongzhaigang NNR 600 ha
Qinglangang PNR 300 ha
Xinying NWP <10 ha
<!--10-->
Dongfang PNR 50 ha
Sanya CNR 50 ha
Total 1000+ ha

actual.comment:
During the inception workshop, the target of 1,000 ha for mangrove replanting was perceived to be unrealistic, because the available land in NRs are very limited. So it was proposed to change the wording of "mangrove replanting" into "mangrove wetland restoration". However, the approval procedure of this revision is not completed. So this issue will be re-discussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office .
Moreover, during the project implementation, it was found that the government stressed too much on mangrove replanting instead of restoring the ecosystem service functions of mangrove wetland. Even worse, fast-growing exotic mangrove species were commonly used in the replanting. To resolve the problem, in March, 2014 the project organized a mangrove restoration expert discussion workshop at the provincial level and in May and June, 4 trainings were conducted for officials from different government apartments in Sanya, Danzhou, Dongfang and Wenchang.
So far, the replanting area for selected sites are:
Dongzhaigang NNR 133.3ha (finished)
Qinglanggang PNR 53.3ha (ongoing)
Xinying NWP 8 ha (ongoing)
Dongfang PNR 57.3ha (finished)
Sanya CNR 36.7ha (ongoing)
Total 288.6ha

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Improved integration of wetland conservation into development and sectoral planning and practices through a strengthened PA System Management Framework including economic valuation of ecosystem services

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Sector specific standards for tourism and coastal fisheries are consistent with international standards for responsible ecotourism and fishery practices

baseline.comment: Existing plans and practices for key sectors including tourism and fishery development do not adequately address key issues for wetland PAs

target.comment: Approval and demonstrated voluntary uptake of sector specific standards for tourism by 20 companies (based on ecotourism category of the ASEAN Tourism Standards) and coastal fisheries by 2 villages (based on the FAO Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and related guidelines)

actual.comment: The project had contacted Haikou Tourism Development Committee to get the draft Regulation on the Management of Mangrove and Rural Tourism Zone. Further study is to be made to look into the existing regulations and plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Key development and sectoral plans such as the 13th 5-year plan and subsidiary plans for key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

baseline.comment: 12th 5-year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism, fisheries, water resources and other key sectors do not adequately address wetland conservation

target.comment: 13th 5-year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism (including the Hainan International Tourism Island Master Plan), fisheries, water resources and other key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

actual.comment: To promote wetland mainstreaming, the project encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities. Moreover, cross-sectoral meetings with relevant local government agencies including environment, water resources, tourism, marine and fishery, forestry were organized in Wenchang, Dongfang and Sanya during the CTA visit in Hainan. Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i) learn about the project ii) have some technical capacity building part to it iii) also facilitate sharing and learning amongst each other.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Establishment of a suitable cross-sectoral body at provincial level to facilitate mainstreaming of wetland conservation into sectoral policies, plans and practices

baseline.comment: Coordination between wetland PA subsystem management and development planning and sectoral planning occurs but is largely responsive and ad hoc

target.comment: A permanent cross-sectoral body is established at provincial level, formally recognized by all sectors and proactively promoting and facilitating strategic inter-sectoral coordination on wetland conservation

actual.comment:
To promote cross sectoral cooperation and the wetland mainstreaming, the project has encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities. Moreover, cross-sectoral meetings and training workshops with relevant local government agencies including environment, water resources, tourism, marine and fishery, forestry were organized in Wenchang, Dongfang, Danzhou, Sanya. Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i) learn about the project ii) have some technical capacity building part to it iii) also facilitate sharing and mutual learning.
To establish a specialized cross-sectoral body on wetland conservation is perceived to be of little chance, because there are already many such bodies on different issues, which are mainly related to a specific national project of significance. So that, during the 2nd PSC meeting, it was approved that the cross-sectoral body will be built on the current PSC by trying to include more government departments.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Awareness of the value of Hainan’s mangrove ecosystem services is increased across a cross-section of provincial audiences (the end-of-project assessment will include gender disaggregated data)

baseline.comment:
(See inset table below for baseline scores and Annex 6 for details
Audiences / Full scores / Scores attained / % of full scores
Officials / 49 / 27.0 / 55
Enterprise / 45 / 22.5 / 50
NGO / 36 / 19.4 / 54
Media / 46 / 26.6 / 58
Student / 40 / 19.4 / 49
Rural / 49 / 15.1 / 31
Urban / 49 / 24.1 / 49
Sub-total / 314 / 154.1 / 49

target.comment:
Baseline + 50% increase in awareness levels using the same methodology in the final year of the project (see inset table below)
Audience / Target % of full scores
Officials / 82
Enterprise / 75
NGO / 81
Media / 87
Student / 73
Rural / 46
Urban / 73
Sub-total / 73

actual.comment:
For major activities of the project, such as the Bird Festival in Dongzhaigang and the MWPAN establishment meeting, media were invited to report. Moreover, with efforts of the communication specialist, reports about birds, wetland resources, mangroves can frequently be seen in the newspaper. In addition, news about project activities was also released on the UNDP China official website.
Several publications were developed, including 2 leaflets of project introduction and common birds in Dongzhaigang, and two handbooks of "Mangrove Plants in Hainan" and "Birds in Dongzhaigang".
In the beginning of 2015, two major awareness-raising events were co-hosted by the project with Hainan Forestry Department, which is the celebration of World Wetland Day in Feburary and the Bird-Loving Week and the World Wildlife Day in March. According to official statistics, in total 2.5 thousand visitors attended the two events, which mostly were urban residents, students from primary and middle school, government officials, NGOs etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Improved data sharing platform for Hainan’s wetland PAs is established, regularly updated and in frequent use by a range of data providers and target audiences

baseline.comment: Data on Hainan’s wetland PAs are dispersed, largely unavailable online, and not regularly updated

target.comment: A centralized database on Hainan’s wetland PAs is accessible to online users, updated on a monthly basis and registers at least 100 hits per month

actual.comment: To develop an on-line database platform, the Project contracted the Network Research & Development Dept. (NRDD) of Research Institute of Forest Resource Information Techniques under Chinese Academy of Forestry. After several rounds of discussion together with the NR management and NRDD, the content of the database was formulated and the first draft of the database platform is foreseen in Sept. 2015.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the management effectiveness of PAs to respond to existing and emerging threats to the globally significant biodiversity and essential ecosystem services in the Altai Mountains and Wetland Landscapes in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Provincial Capacity:
- Forestry Department
- Water Resources Dept.
- Environmental Protection

target.comment: All 70%

actual.comment: Provincial capacity has been enhanced through communication and workshop with relevant sectors. Have no Capacity Scorecards yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Financial sustainability:
- Component : Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks
- Component 2: Business planning and tools for cost-effective management
- Component 3: Tools for revenue generation

actual.comment: Probably will carry out this work in MTR, now we don’t have the Financial Sustainability Scorecards.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase in PA coverage, strengthened resilience and connectivity in the AMWL

baseline.comment: PA network design not optimized for resilience and connectivity

target.comment:
Incorporation of AMNFPPA into AMWL PA framework
Expansion of PA system in AMWL – with total increase of at least 150,000 ha in coverage
Regional collaboration with neighbouring PAs enhanced

actual.comment: 2 wetland parks were established, and the wetland protected area increased further by 4389.52 ha in 2014, which had achieved 2.9% of the total target.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The protection of wetland ecosystems through PA planning and management is enhanced in Altai Prefecture and XUAR through systemic, legal and institutional capacity strengthening

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Existence of effective legal framework for the Xinjiang PA system emplaced, enhancing the conservation status of natural wetlands within the 35 PAs in Xinjiang UAR

baseline.comment:
No provincial level PA regulations w/ guidance for managers or clear stipulation of levels of authority
No sector plans that integrate PA objectives as well as biodiversity

target.comment:
Provincial regulations for PAs proposed by the XFD, including wetland considerations, greater clarity of different management categories, and new framework for co-managed PA zones
At least two sectoral plans integrate PA objectives and biodiversity considerations, such as water resources and agricultural bureaus

actual.comment: <Regulation of Wetland Conservation>has been issued; Carried out researches for 2 times in last year , and provided primary suggestions on revising of PA Regulations.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improved capacity scorecard (SC) scores of Forestry Department for participatory approaches in PA planning and management (Q8 in SC), PA staff competencies (Q9 & 16-19 in SC), and public awareness and support (Q21 in SC)

baseline.comment:
Average score for Q8,9, 16-19 and 21 is 1.43.
Most PA management plans not designed in participatory ways, and not comprehensive; and most PAs not managed collaboratively
Many Forestry and PA staff with inadequate skills for their jobs
Systematic monitoring and reporting systems not established, limited availability or access to information necessary for PA operations, incl. biodiversity and socio-economic development situations in/near PAs

target.comment:
Average score for Q8,9, 16-19 and 21 is 2.4 at minimum, through inter alia the following improvements:
Majority of PAs in AMWL with updated and participatorially prepared management plans, including co-management components
More systematic staff training program designed and initiated
Accessible data and information sharing platform developed under supervision of XFD in support of PA management operationalised
Data sharing platform includes ‘freeform’ categories for observations or information (incl. complaints) submitted anonymously or by the public

actual.comment: This work expected to be done in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Existence of operational safeguard measures to protect wetland habitat and biodiversity from infrastructure placement and mining

baseline.comment:
EIA procedures are not adequately followed leading to undesirable impacts from infrastructure construction and mining.
No legal obligation for post-mining rehabilitation.
No system for reporting malfeasance, or through which to submit formal concerns or complaints or to make suggestions

target.comment:
EIA law is strictly enforced for construction and mining projects affecting wetland PAs, with full participation of the wetland and PA management authorities.
Clear standards are officially set up and enforced with minimum requirements for post-extraction site restoration of mining sites.
Hotline contact number operationalized – also see the information platform above – with referral system (i.e., to other sectors) in place

actual.comment: EIA laws enforced for construction and mining projects affecting wetland PAs, ecosystem experts have chances to participate and provide suggestions on relevant sectors project which influence wetland habitat and biodiversity.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: The biodiversity of the Altai Mountains and Wetland Landscape is effectively conserved with a strengthened PA network and enhanced operational budget through adoption of a landscape level approach to conservation planning and environmental management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Increase in management effectiveness of AMWL PA complex, as per the average METT scores of individual PAs

METT scores:
- Liangheyuan NR 80

actual.comment: The management effectiveness of PA management staffs have been increased through a series of training courses. Buergen Beaver NR has been promoted into NNR, and Kekesu NR of Altay city has been declared NNR and passed trial review, Keketuohai NR of Habahe County is planning to declare NNR.

baseline.comment:
EHI scores:

target.comment:
EHI Scores:
- Liangheyuan NR 75
- Kekesu Wetland NR 75
- Buergen Beaver NR 70

actual.comment: Organized EHI training in every NR while CTA was on his first mission. No data collection yet cause it’s a preliminary arranged activity.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduction in incidence of new mining contracts in PAs in AMWL region

baseline.comment: Gold mining still occurs in some PAs, despite current regulations (but no specific baseline figures available)

target.comment: No mining occurs inside PAs in AMWL region

actual.comment: The human activities in NR of Altay region has been control effectively, no outside people in NR except the herders and management staffs. No new mining contract signed.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Viable alternative options are developed for herding communities, that offset economic dependency on grazing inside PAs

baseline.comment: No assistance available from PA system to help local communities with economic opportunities

target.comment: New co-management structures are in place, which support and strengthen alternative livelihood options for Kazakh herders (and other forms of collaboration)

actual.comment: Trying on developing of alternative plan for herding communities. Supported tourism cooperative of Sandaohaizi increase income through eco-tourism. Organized 4 phase handicrafts training in Chagan township, which helped herders increase income.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Cooperation between Altai-Sayan Ecoregion countries is enhanced

baseline.comment:
No conservation action plan for Chinese beaver
No relationship between two adjacent NRs in Altai Mtns

target.comment:
Beaver conservation action plan developed and adopted (agreed) by Altai Prefecture and the local government in Mongolia
Tavan Bogd NP – Liangheyuan NR partnership MOU is reached

actual.comment: Established cooperation relationship with Tavan Bogd NP of Mongolia, had communications and visits for two times and Memorandum of Cooperation was signed.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Operational budgets for PAs in AMWL increase

baseline.comment: Operational budget for AMWL PA network is US$ 1,515,594 per year

target.comment: Operational budget is increased by 40%, with new contributions from local, prefecture and provincial government

actual.comment: Operational budget for AMWL PA network has not been calculated yet.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: The adoption and development of a ‘community co-management’ approach to conservation in Liangheyuan Nature Reserve demonstrates improved management effectiveness for a wetland PA in the Altai Mountains and Wetland Landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Reduction in biodiversity pressure from overgrazing

baseline.comment:
7,000 herding families graze livestock in the NR in summer, incl. 170 families (approx. 40,000 stock) in ecologically sensitive Sandaohaizi wetland
Management zones in Liangheyuan NR not rationalized

target.comment:
Livestock numbers reduced by 20% in Sandaohaizi wetland, with economic burden to local people offset with alternative (complementary) livelihoods
Zoning of Liangheyuan NR re-assessed and modified based on EHI surveys with illegal mining banned in core/buffer zones and grazing banned in core zones

actual.comment: Some of the herder families from Sandaohaizi are trying to change from herding to business, livestock numbers reduced a little, no statistic data yet. The core zone of Liangheyuan NR is under strict management ,no human activities. In addition of local herders, the activities in buffer zone is reducing.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Enhanced socio-economic options to compensate for lost opportunities improving local economic situation

baseline.comment:
Community ecotourism not present in project area (Liangheyuan NR)
Avg. household income is 1,980 CNY/year in Sandaohaizi community

target.comment:
At least 3 community tourism ventures established, bringing benefit to at least 30 families serving as a model for up-scaling
Average household income for park residents increased by at least 20%, as a result of new livelihood opportunities

actual.comment: Supported tourism cooperative which established by 10 herder families of Sandaohaizi, increased income through eco-tourism. Also organized training courses of handicrafts and cooking in Sandaohaizi area, trying to enhance socio-economic options.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduction in biodiversity pressure from mining

baseline.comment: 6,800 ha of PA land in NR is still threatened by mining activities

target.comment: Illegal gold mining activities stopped in NR, and restoration of 800 ha of land previously degraded by mining

actual.comment: Totally stopped the illegal mining activities in Liangheyuan NR. And covered 300 ha of previous degraded land, planted blackcurrant in some part of the restoration area.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Populations of threatened species (beavers, moose, wolverine) are stable

baseline.comment:
Wildlife populations:
Beaver = 300-400
Moose = tbd
Wolverine = tbd

target.comment: All select wildlife populations are stable or increasing

actual.comment: Through visit the local families and monitoring known the population of threatened species are increasing, can notice ibex, red deer regularly; and spotted the brown bear, wolve and sable by infrared camera.

location.name: Heilongjiang Sheng
